[G-C and A-T pairing] [DNA packaging]
The first image shows the complementary base pairing between G-C and A-T. The second image displays DNA packaging.

G-C and A-T pairing refers to the pairing of certain nucleotides in DNA. Specifically, the nitrogen-containing bases (the letters in the image) pair up with one another based on the number of hydrogen bonds they make: two for G-C and three for A-T.

DNA packaging, on the other hand, refers to the process by which DNA is compacted and organized within the cell. DNA is usually stored in a structure called chromosomes, which consist of long strands of DNA wrapped around proteins called histones. The diagram in the second image illustrates the relationship between chromosome size and DNA folding.

In summary, both images are related to the structure and organization of DNA, but they focus on different aspects: base pairing (first image) and DNA packaging (second image). The common theme is that both processes are essential for the proper functioning of cellular processes involving DNA.
